title: Mises Ã  jour sur F-Droid
content: Mises Ã  jour sur F-DroidVous avez vu quâ€™il y avait une nouvelle version dâ€™AntennaPod et vous vous interrogezÂ :  Pourquoi la derniÃ¨re version nâ€™est-elle pas encore sur F-Droidâ€¯?  quand la nouvelle version sera-t-elle disponible sur F-Droid?Due to the different steps and because we are not involved in publishing releases on F-Droid, we canâ€™t tell when exactly the latest version will be available there.En brefÂ : cela peut prendre un certain temps. Nous vous demandons dâ€™Ãªtre patients.Les Ã©tapes pour obtenir une nouvelle version sur F-Droid  We release a beta version, which is only available through Google Play due to technical limitations in F-Droid.  We do a slow, gradual roll-out to all Google Play users. That way we make sure that there are no critical bugs. This can take several weeks.  We create a release on GitHub. We do this only after the roll-out on Google Play is complete.  F-Droid systems check the AntennaPod repository and detect a new release. The update checker server runs daily (overnight in Europe).  AprÃ¨s que F-Droid ait dÃ©tectÃ© une nouvelle version dâ€™AntennaPod, il construit lâ€™application. Ainsi, F-Droid sâ€™assure que lâ€™application que vous tÃ©lÃ©chargez correspond bien au code source publiÃ© par AntennaPod. Comme il y a beaucoup dâ€™applications Ã  construire, le serveur F-Droid prend 1 Ã  2 jours supplÃ©mentaires pour construire lâ€™application.  An F-Droid contributor signs the build cryptographically. To improve security, the contributor needs to take the app and physically walk it to a dedicated computer which is not connected to the internet. When all apps are signed, the contributor uploads them to the F-Droid systems. This usually takes 1 to 2 days.  Vous avez vu quâ€™il y avait une nouvelle version dâ€™AntennaPod et vous vous interrogezÂ :At this point we consider it â€˜released on F-Droidâ€™. But remember that your F-Droid client (the â€˜app storeâ€™) also needs to refresh its local copy of the index. Only after that youâ€™ll get prompted about the latest AntennaPod release.So, whatâ€™s the ETA?As you can see, there are a lot of steps which each take a varying amount of time. We usually take well over a month between releasing a beta version and tagging the release on GitHub. After the release is tagged, F-Droid usually takes four to six days to process it.Ce que vous pouvez faire si la procÃ©dure prend plus de temps que prÃ©vuDid we not tag the release on GitHub yet? Then please just wait. The update is in beta and not ready for public release.We did tag the release on GitHub? As the F-Droid team notes: â€œdonâ€™t panic before 7 days have passed, please.â€  Did those 7 days pass since we tagged the release on GitHub? Feel free to let us know by creating a post on our forum. Weâ€™ll take a look.  Did we tag the release 7 days ago or less? Then please just wait. Or investigate where we are in the process.Investigate current statusIf you want, you can follow these steps to get an idea of the progress:  Check if and when the release was tagged on GitHub (you may need to hover, for example, â€˜last weekâ€™ to see the exact date on GitHub). If so, it should soon be picked up by the update checker.  Check if F-Droidâ€™s AntennaPod versions list was updated since then. If so, it should soon be processed by the build server.  Check if AntennaPod was built in the running cycle or the last cycle. You can also use the app F-Droid build status for this. If so, it should soon be cryptographically signed by an F-Droid contributor.          Note that thereâ€™s no queue for apps that need to be built. AntennaPod is not listed in the success and fail lists yet, and you want to know if it will be built?                  click on â€˜fdroiddata versionâ€™ @ commit of a build cycle          click on â€˜Browse filesâ€™          click on â€˜Find fileâ€™          Le paquet doit Ãªtre de.danoeh.antennapod          open the file          check if it includes the latest release

title: Listening statistics
content: Listening statisticsAntennaPod has a statistics screen that lets you view the number of listening hours per subscription and per month. However, these statistics arenâ€™t always as precise as they could be.Why the stats arenâ€™t preciseTo track statistics, AntennaPod records two things for each episode:  Played duration: how long the episode was played (e.g. 6 minutes if a 3-minute episode was played twice)  Last played: the date and time when playback was last paused or stopped for the episodeBoth are updated each time playback is paused or stopped. This information is used to calculate totals by adding up the â€˜played durationâ€™ of all episodes whose â€˜last playedâ€™ date falls within a given month.This approach means that if you listen to 7 minutes of an episode today and 38 minutes of that episode tomorrow, all 45 minutes are attributed to tomorrow. The same applies across months. If an episode is played both in June and July, all listening time is attributed to July. Similarly, if an episode is played both in December of one year and in January of the next, it is attributed to the second year.The monthly statistics are usually accurate because they look at a longer time period. However, day-by-day statistics would have a higher risk of becoming unreliable, which is why AntennaPod does not offer those.Why we donâ€™t want to change itStats (or rather: graphs) are fun. So why donâ€™t we record information differently to allow for more filter options and more granular data in AntennaPod?It would be possible, for example, to record for each episode how long it was played on each day. For instance:  28 June: 7 minutes  30 June: 38 minutes  1 July: 19 minutesThereâ€™s two main reasons. Firstly, while statistics are fun, we rather spend time on AntennaPodâ€™s main purpose: playing podcasts. Changing to this new approach would require time now to implement it (rewriting the code that saves playback time in the database) and time in future to maintain a more complex system.Secondly, AntennaPod would take up more space on your phone - espcially for loyal users who stick with the app for several years. Thatâ€™s because instead of a single row per episode in the database we would need to store multiple rows for each played episode to store the playback duration, which causes the database size to increase.We hope youâ€™ll enjoy the month-based statistics! ğŸ“Š (If you happen to be a web developer interested in making a dedicated dashboard for AntennaPod statistics based on database exports, please do ping us on the forum.)
